overview.short: Thermoactinomyces are thermophilic, Gram-positive, aerobic bacteria with filamentous/coryneform habit that appear as rods under simplified schemas; colonies are typically dry and powdery, and many species form heat-resistant spores.
overview.clinical_context: Occasionally recovered from environmental exposures (compost, hay, dust). Classical association with hypersensitivity pneumonitis in agricultural settings; human invasive disease is rare.

field_notes.Shape: Genus shows filamentous/coryneform habit; mapped to 'Rods' per your allowed Shape categories.
field_notes.Growth Temperature: Thermophilic growth is characteristic; many isolates grow robustly at ≥50 °C.
field_notes.Spore Formation: Heat-resistant spores are typical and aid survival in compost/hay.

key_differentiators.notes: Thermophilic growth at ≥50 °C supports Thermoactinomyces over many mesophilic actinomycetes.
Heat-resistant spore formation (not aerial conidia) helps separate from classic Streptomyces.
Catalase positivity with thermophilic, dry chalky colonies favors Thermoactinomyces.

common_confusions.reason: Both linked to farm environments and hypersensitivity pneumonitis; colony textures can appear similar.
Thermotolerant, spore-forming Gram-positive organisms may be misread as Bacillus if filamentous habit is overlooked.

when_to_question_identification: No growth at ≥50 °C argues against Thermoactinomyces.
Strongly mucoid or wet colonies are atypical; reconsider identification.
Oxidase positivity would be unusual and should trigger re-evaluation.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Confirms thermophilic growth profile characteristic of the genus.
Practical species-level confirmation for environmental actinomycetes.
Definitive identification when MALDI confidence is low or taxonomic boundaries are in flux.
